CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Candidates

Certificants

Registrants
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Source:  CFP Board
 
Candidate:  a person who has applied to CFP Board to take the CFP® Certification Examination, but who has not yet met all of the certification requirements. 
 
Certificant:  individuals who are currently certified by CFP Board
 
Registrant:   individuals who are not currently certified but have been certifed in the past and have an entitlement, direct or indirect, to potentially use the CFP®marks. This includes individuals who have relinquished their certification and who are eligible for reinstatement without being required to pass the current exam.  TheStandards of Professional Conduct  apply to registrants when the conduct at issue occurred at a time when the registrant was certified; CFP Board has jurisdiction to investigate such conduct.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Conflict of Interest
CardContent.FlashCardBack: A CFP® certificant who is a Registered Representative at the very minimum must disclose his/her broker-dealer relationship to the client.  The CFP® certificant who has an insurance license should disclose that relationship with the client.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Prior to entering into an agreement, the certificant shall provide written information or discuss what?
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Rule 1.2 - 1 requires a CFP®to disclose/discuss the obligations and responsibilities of each party under the agreement with respect to:
  1. Defining goals, needs, and objectives
  2. Gathering and providing appropriate data,
  3. Examining the result of the current course of action without changes, 
  4. The formulation of any recommended actions,
  5. Implementation responsibilities, and
  6. Monitoring responsibilities.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Written Agreement
Specifications
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Rule 1.3
  1. The parties to the Agreement,
  2. The date of the Agreement, 
  3. How and on what terms each party can terminate the Agreement, and
  4. The services to be provided as part of the Agreement.

that must be disclosed

  • 12b-1 fees  
  • Cash bonuses
  • Trailing commissions
  • Compensation from wrap-free programs
  • Ticket charges
  • Fees on mutual funds
  • Solicitation fees

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Commingle Client Funds
Permitted / Not Permitted
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Permitted: Commingling one or more client's funds or other property together is permitted, subject to compliance with applicable legal requirements and provided accurate records are maintained for each client.  Client funds can be commingled in a common client investment account.

Not Permitted:  CFP® certificant may not commingle client funds with the funds of the financial planning firm.

and

Rules

  • Whether terms and conditions are fair and reasonable to client

Exceptions to Borrowing (client loaning to practitioner)

  • When client is a family member
  • When client is a financial institution with normal business activity

CardContent.FlashCardFront: A certificant shall notify CFP Board of changes to contact information within ____ days.
CardContent.FlashCardBack: 45 days including information such as e-mail address, telephone number, and physical address

CardContent.FlashCardFront: A certificant shall notify CFP Board in writing of any conviction of a crime within ____ days.
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
This is Article 13.2.
30 calendar days after the date on which the certificant is notified of the conviction, suspension, or bar

Rule 6.4 says 10 days.  Use 30 days 
 
NOTE: Mere charge/accusation of criminal felony does not require notification

  2. Article 12 Appeal to order
  3. Article 15 Required action after revocation

CardContent.FlashCardBack:

  2. Pre-hearing

  3. Petition to appeal with 30 days of decision

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Fitness Standards - applies to candidates and to reinstated registrants
 
What will always bar an individual from becoming certified?
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Felony convictions resulting in revocation of a professional license for conviction of the following crimes:
  • DUI*
  • theft
  • embezzlement
  • financially-based crimes
  • revocation of license by regulators (e.g. SEC, FINRA, state)
  • tax fraud
  • related crimes
    • murder
    • rape

*If the charge is just DUI with no injury, no problem.  If the charge is DUI with injury there will be a higher possibility of revocation.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Major Federal Securities Acts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Securites Act of 1933- Requires thatnewissues purchasers be provided with a detailed prospectus before a purchase was completed.

Securites Act of 1934- Regulates thesecondarymarket (trading ofissuedsecurities).  Act also created the SEC to enforce securities laws.

Investment CompanyAct of 1940- Authorized the SEC to regulate unit investment trusts (UITs) and managed investment companies (closed-end and open-end funds) plus variable products.

Securities Investors ProtectionAct of 1970- Established the SIPC to supervise securities firms that get into financial difficulties.  The SIPC insures investors against losses arising from thefailureof a brokerage firm.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Avoiding Gift Tax on 529 Funding
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Up to 5 times annual gift tax exclusion ($15,000 in 2018) or $75,000 may be deposited to 529 with no gift tax
    - presumes donor lives 5 years
  • Gift splitting results in a $150,000 deposit without gift tax

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Change of 529 Beneficiary
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• The owner can change the beneficiary
  • Approved beneficiaries if afamily memberof original beneficiary:
    • Parent / Stepparent
    • Grandparent/Grandchild
    • Child / Stepchild
    • Sibling
    • Stepbrother / stepsister
    • Niece / nephew
    • Aunt / uncle
    • Brother-in-law / sister-in-law
    • Father-in-law / mother-in-law
    • Daughter-in-law / son-in-law
    • First cousin
    • Spouse

CardContent.FlashCardFront: 529 Rollover
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If the owner rolls over the value of the prepaid account to another beneficiary in a generation below that of the current beneficiary, rolloverwill be treatedas a taxable gift.
  • If the rollover stays in the same generation, there is no taxable gift.

Coverdell ESAs
(Educaton Savings Accounts)
Contributions
Characteristics
Limitations
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Contributions
  • Up to $2K/yr Coverdell ESA to benefit each child under age 18
  • Not deductible
  • Earnings accumulate tax-deferred
  • Amounts are distributed free of tax & penalities - qualified use
     
    Characteristics

• Tuition, fees, tutoring, special needs services, books, and supplies
  • Room and board, uniforms, transportation, and extended day programs

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Kiddie Tax
General Principles
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Will now be taxed like trust income
  • The parents rates do not apply
Not over $2,550 taxed at 10%
$2,550 - $9,150 taxed at $255 + 24% over $2,550
$9,150 - $12,500 taxed at $1,839 + 35% over $9,150
over $12,500 taxed at $3,012 + 37% over $12,500

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Education Saving Bonds
EE Bonds

(for tax-free EE bond redemption)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Bonds are normally purchased in the parent's name
  • Savings bonds can be in an UTMA account, but then cannot qualify for the educational expense exclusion.  If redeemed for college tuition, interest is taxable.
  • Bonds must be redeemed in a year in which the owner pays qualified higher education expenses, defined as tuition and fees only.
  • Interest fully exempt from federal income tax only
  • For parents to receive full benefit as tax-free status, parent's adjusted gross income must be below certain thresholds

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Who can own EE education bonds? 

    Can EE education bonds be owned
              by an UTMA account?
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Only a person over 24 normally a parent. 


No, only a person over 24 or a parent.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Financial Aid Options
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Pell Grants: Available to full-time students as well as those carrying six or more credit hours; maximum award $5,920 maximum

Parent Loan for Undergraduate Students PLUS:  non-need based as anyone can apply

Perkins Loans: College decides on whether the student needs the loan.  Student can borrow up to $4,000 per year - up to total of $20,000

Subsidized Stafford Student Loans:  Available to students who show financial need; loan is limited

Supplemental Education Opportunity Grants: Available for Pell Grants recipients only and offer up to $4,000 per year

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Economic Policies
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Fiscal Policy: federal taxation and spending designed to level out the business cycle

Monetary Policy:  Federal Reserve Board influences the growth of money supply

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Repo vs. Reverse Repo
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
One of the tools of the Federal Reserve Board that influences short-term

Repo: Fed buys securities - expansionary / easy money policy

Reverse Repo:Fed sells securities - contractionary / tight money policy

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Recession vs. Depression
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Recession: two consecutive quarters of decline in real GDP

Depression: severe or long recession (6 quarters)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Buy
vs.
Lease / Rent
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Buying a Home - Advantages
Tax deductions for interest and property taxes

Capital gains on the sale of the in excess of the exclusion ($250,000 single/married filing separately; $500,000 MFJ) 

Renting a Home - Advantages
Rent could be lower than a mortgage payment, this would equate to additional savings.   

NOTE: Normally the higher the marginal tax bracket, the greater the advantage of owning a home. You must also consider the time frame. Living in an area for a short period of time would favor renting, whereas a long period would favor ownership.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Types of Bankruptcy
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Chapter 11:not qualified for Chapter 13 because debt
exceeds limitations or do not have regular source of income

Chapter 13:reorganization; debtor is not required to relinquish assets

Chapter 7:permits debtor to claim either federal or state exemptions

Debts that are not cancelable by bankruptcy are students loans, government loans, child support, or alimony.

NOTE:  Only Chapter 7 is covered and tested.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)


Key Licenses
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Series 6: Sells mutual funds, UITs, and variables (only new UITs)

Series 7: Sells all general securities EXCEPT commodities and certain options

Series 63: Uniform Securities Agent State Law Exam; designed to qualify candidates as securities agents

Series 65: Uniform Investment Advisor Law Exam; designed to qualify candidates as investment adviser representatives

Series 66: Uniform Combined State Law Exam; designed to qualify candidates as both securities agents and investment adviser representatives

CardContent.FlashCardFront: What is a Fiduciary
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Person, company, or association holding assets in trust for a beneficiary
  • Charged with the responsibility of investing money wisely for the beneficiary's benefit
  • Owes utmost good faith

EXAMPLES

  • Executors of wills and estates
  • Receivers in bankruptcy
  • Trustees
  • Those who administer the assets belonging to underage or incompentent beneficiaries

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Integrity
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Client's interest first and foremost

  • Violated by generating excessive compensation to the CFP®professional

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Objectivity
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• CFP®must be objective as to his/her abilities 

  • Planner must recommend product in light of each clients needs

  • Violated by failing to call in other experts needed or recommending same products to all clients

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Competence
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• CFP®must stay current with new rules and products 

  • Violated if 30 hours of continuing education is not completed every 2 years

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Fairness
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• CFP®must disclose material information to prospective and current clients.

  • Violated when CFP®receivesundisclosed
    commissions and referral fees

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Confidentiality
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Client information not to be shared with third parties unless: 
  • Client grants permission

  • CFP® receives court or regulatory order (IRS/SEC)

  • Information needed for CFP®to defend self against charges from client

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Professionalism
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• CFP®must conduct business in a professional manner

  • Violated failing to supervise subordinates

  • Violated by bashing competitor CFP®professionals

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Code of Ethics

Principle of Diligence
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• CFP®must research products

  • CFP®must research other professionals before recommending them 

  • Violated by recommending an investment without understanding its risk

  • Violated by recommending an attorney without knowing his/her experience

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Medicare A covers
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Hospital stays are subject to a deductible for the first 60 days, then a second deductible for the next 30 days, and third deductible for another 60 days. Inpatient hospital care is limited to 150 days for one stay. 

  • Post-hospital extended care in a skilled nursing home up to 100 days

  • An unlimited number of post-hospital home health services 

  • Hospice care for terminally ill patients

  • Patient pays for 1st 3 pints of blood or donates them

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Medicare B covers
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Diagnostic tests
  • Radiology / pathology
  • Transfusion of blood
  • Physical / occupational therapy
  • Drugs and biologicals that cannot be self-administered
  • Outpatient services from a participating hospital for diagnosis or treatment
  • Unlimited number of home health services
  • Free preventive care services like colorectal cancer screening and mammograms
  • Free annual physical to develop and update preventive plan 
  • Depression screening, alcohol counseling, obesity, behavioral therapy for cardiovascular disease

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Medicare Part D
for Outpatient Prescriptions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Private insurance for outpatient prescription drugs

  • Manufacturers required to provide substantial discounts

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Medicare
does NOT cover
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Foot care, dental care, glasses, hearing aids, most immunizations except one flu shot per year

  • Emergency care outside the U.S. (except Canada, Mexico, Caribbean, and U.S. territorial waters)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Health Savings Account
HSA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Must have a HDHP to qualify to open an account 
  • Distributions tax-free if used for eligible health care
  • Contributions not spent are carried forward in the owner's name and are portable to a spouse.
  • Unused assets become property of named beneficiary upon death.
  • Distributions for non-medical are ordinary income taxable plus 20% penalty if under 65.
  • Both employers and employees can contribute.
  • Can be used to pay for qualified LTC premiums.
NOTE:  Over-the-counter drugs do not qualify.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Examples of HSA Qualifed Expenses
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Doctor visits and test not covered by your insurance policy 
  • Surgical procedures and hospitalization related charges not covered by your insurance 
  • Prescription drugs 
  • Acupuncture & chiropractic care 
  • Eye exams, glasses, and laser surgery 
  • Hearing test and hearing aids 
  • Dental exams, dental work, and dentures 
  • Alcohol and drug abuse treatment 
  • Insulin and diabetic testing supplies 
  • Long term care related expenses

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Disability Insurance Policies

Definitions of Disability
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1.Own occupation - best definition for insured
2.Modified any occupation
3.Split definition - own then modified
4.Any occupation (Social Security definition)
5.Loss of income

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Disability Income

Policy Continuance Provisions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Noncancellable "noncan": continuous term policy guaranteeing the insured's right to maintain the policy at the stated premium

Guaranteed renewable:  continuous right to maintain the policy but the insurer may increase the premium by a class of insureds

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Elimination Period
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Acts like a waiting period or a deductible
  • The longer the waiting period, the lower the premium
  • Older policies written for 30 days
  • Current policies often written for 90 days

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Taxation of Disability Policies
Taxation of Premiums and Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Theindividualowns the contract andpaysthe premium.
  • Premiums are not deductible.
  • Benefits are tax-free to the employee.
The employee owns the contract, and theemployer paysthe entire premium under a bonus arrangement.  (Section 162 disability insurance)
  • Premiums are deductible by the employer as a bonus (business expense).
  • Benefits are tax-free to the employee, but premiums are taxable.
The employee owns the contract, and theemployer paysthe entire premium under a salary continuation plan (typical group disability policy).
  • Premiums are deductible by the employer.
  • Benefits are taxable to the employee.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Partnership / S Corp Shareholders
Taxation Rules
for Disability Insurance
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Step 1: Cost of health insurance must be on the company books (deducted by the business)
 
Step 2: Cost of insurance is are additional taxable income to partner or greater than 2% shareholder

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Normal Eligibility
for Long-Term care Insurance Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The insured is unable to perform at least two activities of daily living (ADLs).  

ADL examples:
  • eating 
  • bathing
  • dressing
  • transferring from a bed to a chair
  • using the toilet
  • maintaining continence

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
5 conditions to qualify a patient
for skilled nursing benefits
under Medicare A
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• The patient's condition requires skilled nursing.
  • The patient has been in a hospital at least three days in a row before admission to a participating skilled nursing facility.
  • The patient is admitted to the skilled nursing facility within a short time (generally within 30 days) after leaving the hospital.
  • The patient's care in the skilled nursing facility is for a condition that was treated in the hospital. 
  • A medical professional certifies that the patient needs and receives skilled nursing care.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Flexible Spending Account

FSA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Contributions are not subject to income tax, FICA, FUTA
  • Health FSA may not be used to reimburse an employee's premium paid for other health plans (such as a MSA, HSA, and LTC).
  • Expenses for long-term care services cannot be reimbursed under a health FSA, but other expenses can be reimbursed.
  • Medical expenses is limited to $2,650. Dependent care FSA is limited to $5,000 and must be used by year end.
  • Employers may offer up to $500 in unused FSA funds to carryover, or they can carry over the excess the extra 2½ months.  Only one of the two options is allowed not both. Employers are not required to offer either option.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Eligible Services
under a Dependent Care FSA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Placement fees for a dependent care provider, such as an au pair (domestic assistant working for a family)
  • Before and after-school care (not tuition)
  • Care of an incapacitated adult who lives with you at least eight hours a day
  • Childcare at day camp, nursery school, or by a private sitter
  • Late pick-up fees
  • Expenses for a housekeeper whose duties include caring for an eligible dependent
  • Summer or holiday days camps, including registration fees
  • Activities in lieu of day care when the fees associated with the activity are incidental to, or cannot be separated from cost of care (swimming, music lessons, etc)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Services NOT Eligible 
under a Dependent Care FSA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Education or tuition fees
  • Expenses for children age 13 and older
  • Late payment fees 
  • Overnight camps
  • Payment for services not yet provided (advanced payments)
  • Field trips, clothing and food
  • Transportation to and from the dependent care provider

CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Split dollar life insurance
  • IRC Section 162 bonus plan
  • Death-benefit only plan

VEBA 
under 501(c)(9) funded benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Death benefits (may also be used to pre-fund retiree benefits)
  • Medical expense benefits (may also be used to pre-fund retiree health coverage)
  • Disability benefits
  • Legal expense benefits
  • Unemployment benefits
  • Child care benefits
  • Severance benefits

NOTE:  NOT non-qualified deferred compensation plans

CardContent.FlashCardBack:

Low Risk Tolerance

Policy Owners

Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages
  • Provides permanent protection

Disadvantages

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Modified Endowment Contract

MEC
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Entered into after June 21,1988
  • Fails to meet the "seven pay test" (includes ALL single premium policies)
  • Distributions/withdrawals are taxed LIFO (interest-first rule)
  • Distributions under 59½ also subject to 10% federal penalty tax (if not disabled)
  • Death benefit is tax-free

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
"MEC" Grandfather
Life Insurance Rules
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If the death benefit increases by $150K or less and the insured has guaranteed insurability (no proof of insurability), the policy willNOTlose its grandfathered (non MEC) status.

  • If the policy increases byANYamount and the insured must prove insurability, the policy MAYlose its grandfathered (non MEC) status.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
When Life Insurance Benefits
are Income Taxable due to
Transfer for Value
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
If a policy is transferred from one owner to another for valuable consideration (typically money), the income tax exclusion is lost (like a viatical).  The four mainexceptionsto this rule are the following:

  • A sale or transfer to the insured
  • A sale or transfer to a partner or partnership in which the insured is a partner
  • A corporation in which the insured is a shareholder or officer
  • If ordered by divorce court

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Life Insurance Contracts
1035 Tax Free Exchange Rules
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Life  → Life (OK)

Life → Annuity Contract (OK)

Annuity Contract → Annuity Contract (OK)

Annuity → Life(not tax-free)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Viatication

 vs.

 Life Settlements
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Viatication:  payments refers to the sale of a terminally or chronically ill person's life insurance policy to a business firm that specializes in such transactions

Life Settlements:  describes a transaction involving an insured who is not terminally or chronically ill and is generally over age 65.  This also may produce a capital gain outcome.  

terminally ill = less than 2 years to live

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Insurance Funded Agreements

Buy Sell
Stock Redemption
vs.
Cross Purchase
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Stock Redemption: 

  • No step-up in cost basis to remaining owner
  • Premium is not deductible
  • Death benefit is income tax-free

Cross-Purchase: 

  • Step-up in basis to remaining owner
  • Premium is not deductible
  • Death benefit is income tax-free

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Tax consequences of Buy-Sell
arrangements due to
death or disablity
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Death: Stock will get a step-up in basis/no income tax will be due when redeemed; value is included in deceased owner's estate  
 
Disability: Appreciation in stock value will be subject to income tax when redeemed by the disabled owner

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Split-Dollar Life Insurance

EndoRsement Method

 vs.

Collateral aSSignment Method
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
EndorRsement Method: 

  • EmployeRis the owneR.
  • Employee is not a shareholder.
  • Employer retains cash value or premium paid if greater.

Collateral aSSignment Method:

  • Employee is owner.
  • Employee is aShareholder.
  • Employee aSSigns the policy. 
  • Employee gets balance of cash value above premium paid or beneficiary gets balance of death benefits.

CardContent.FlashCardBack:

 Expected Return x  # of months

Lump Sum payouts
LIFO (interest first rule)
Ordinary income plus 10% penalty under 59½
 
NOTE:  Prior to 1982 taxed FIFO (principle first rule) and 10% penalty

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Non-natural Person Rule
for Annuity Contracts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
If an annuity contract is held by an entity who is not a natural person (corporation or trust), the annuity taxation rules change.  

The income on the contract must be treated as ordinary income received or accrued by the holder that year.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Auto Insurance Policy Coverages
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Part A - liability (limited to third parties)
  • Part B - medical payments
  • Part C - uninsured motorists
  • Part D - damage to the covered auto

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Personal Auto Policy
PAP

Requirements
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Can be written on eligible vehicles owned
    and leased by an individual or by a
    husband or wife living in the same household.
  • Vehicle rented to others as a public or livery conveyance is not eligible and must be insured under a commerical policy.
  • Eligible vehicles include private passenger automobiles such as cars, vans, and sport utility vehicles.
  • Vans and pickups are ineligible for coverage if they are used for transportation or delivery of goods and materials.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Part A - Liability Coverage
definition
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Provides protection against judgments and covered exposures resulting from bodily injury and property damage liability deemed to have been caused by the insured (BI/PD)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Part B - Medical Payments
Med-Pay
Definition and Coverage
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Provides payment for the reasonable and necessary medical expenses of an insured as a result of an automobile accident
  • Only expenses for medical services rendered within 3years of the date of an accident are covered
Covered for Med Pay
  • Named insured, spouse, and any family member occupying auto or when struck as a pedestrian
  • Any other person who is injured while occupying covered auto

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Part C
Uninsured Motorist Coverage
UM
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Insurer agrees to pay compensatory damages that an insured is legally entitled to recover from the owner or operator of an uninsured motor vehicle because ofbodily injury.  The coverage applies to claims for medical expenses, lost wages, and pain/suffering but does not include punitive or exemplary damages. Insured for uninsured motoristcoverage as follows:

  • Named insured and any family member
  • Any other person who occupies a covered auto
  • Any person who is entitled to recover damages due to injury to a person described above

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Part D
Coverage: Damage to your Auto
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Collision: Defined as "the upset of your covered auto or its impact with another vehicle or object"

Other than collision: Breakage of glass, or loss caused by the following
 
Falling ObjectsHail
FireWater
TheftFlood
ExplosionRiotor civil commotion
EarthquakeWindstorm
Contact with birds or animals

NOTE: Towing is covered under collision and other than collision

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Umbrella Liability Insurance
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• For exam, almost always a correct answer, since it is smart coverage
  • Provides liability coverage (BI/PD) for catastrophic legal claims or judgments
  • Requires policy owner to carry certain underlying coverage of specified minimum amounts

NOTE: Professional acts are specifically EXCLUDED.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Umbrella Liability Insurance
exclusions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Any act committed with the intent to cause personal injury or property damage
  • Damage to property owned by the insured
  • Business pursuits and workers compensation obligations
  • Rendering of or failure to render professional services (malpractice)
  • Directors' and officers' activities
  • Workers' compensation obligations

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Business Owner's Policy
BOP
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Designed for small-to-medium-size businesses

  • Policy is package that has real property, contents, and liability protection

  • Professionally liability is specifically excluded

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Workers' Compensation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Unlimited medical expenses including occupational disease benefits; no deductibles

  • Disability income (total and partial); tax free; equal to employee's average weekly pay

  • Death benefits payable to family member

  • Rehabilitation (medical and vocational)

  • Can be referred to as absolute liability

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Professional Liability
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Malpractice:  Substandard conduct results in bodily injury (example:  doctors, dentists)


Errors and Omissions (E&O): Substandard conduct results in property damage or monetary damages such as loss of money (example:  financial planners, lawyers, accountants, insurance agents, etc.)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Banker's Acceptance
CardContent.FlashCardBack: This instrument is used to finance imports and exports. Before a foreign exporter will ship goods to the U.S., the exporter wants assurance of payment when the goods arrive.  Banker's acceptances are bearer securities and can be held to maturity or can be traded.  The maturity is 9 months or less, and the banker's acceptance trades at a discount to face value.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Yankee Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Definition: Dollar-denominated bonds issued in the U.S. by foreign banks and corporations. The bonds are issued in the U.S. when market conditions are more favorable than on the Eurobond market or in domestic markets overseas.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
How Individual Bonds Work


What is the face value of a par value bond
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Bond:  Bonds are a debt security which obligates the issuer to pay interest (usually semiannually) and to repay the principal amount when the debt matures.

Par Value:  Bonds are issued with a stated par value (face value usually $1,000) and a stated rate of interest (coupon rate or nominal rate).

Discount Bond: Bond sells at a discount when par value is inexcess of the bond's purchaseprice.

Premium Bond: Bond sells at a premium when the bond's purchase price is in excess of par value.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Original Issue Discount Bonds
OID
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Bond is discounted from PAR VALUE at the time of issue.
  • Many original issue discount bonds are zero-coupon bonds originally sold far below par value and pay no interest until maturity when it pays par value
  • Discount on bond must be accreted over the bond's life.
  • Each year the portion of the discount that has been earned is included as taxable interest income, and bond's basis is increased.
  • Zero-coupon bond owner must report interest income although the bond pays no interest before maturity (phantom income).
  • Annual accretion amount is non-taxable municipal interest income.  If held to maturity, there is no capital gain or loss.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Comparison between
Treasury Bills, Notes, and Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Bills mature in 3-12 months andare quoted in terms of discounted yield($100 to $1 million).  The difference between issue price and maturity is taxed as interest.
  • Notes are intermediate debt maturing in 1-10 years ($1,000 to $100,000) .
  • Bonds are long-term debt maturing in 10-30 years ($1,000 to $1 million).
NOTE:  Interest is taxed at federal rate, no state or local income tax.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Treasury Inflation-Protection Securites
TIPS
CardContent.FlashCardBack: The investor is taxed annually on the interest payment plus the appreciation in face value.  The increase in face value is only nominal or"phantom"income that is not collectible until the bond is sold or matures.  However, this income is taxable in the year it is accrued.  TIPS are not subject to state and local taxes.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
EE Bonds

Can EE bonds be in an UTMA

Can EE education bonds be in an UTMA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Non-marketable, nontransferable, cannot be used for collateral
  • Sold at face value
  • Interest rate based on the 10-year Treasury note yields
  • Fixed interest rate that is in effect at the time of purchase
  • Subject to federal taxation when redeemed (unless used as education bonds)
  • Not subject to state or local taxes

    Yes, bonds can be in an UTMA   

    No EE education bonds have to be owned by someone age 24 or older.  Normally owned by a parent.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: HH Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Americans still own old HH bonds
  • No longer exchangeable for EE bonds
  • Was only available by exchanging at least $500 in Series EE bonds.
  • Pay semiannually (by check) subject to federal tax only
  • Nonmarketable

CardContent.FlashCardFront: I Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Nonmarketable, nontransferable, cannot be used for collateral
  • Sold at face value
  • Interest is composed of two parts:
    • a fixed base rate (remains same for the life of the bond)
    • an inflation adjustment (adjusted every six months)
    • subject to federal taxation when redeemed (unless used as education bonds)
    • not subject to state or local taxes

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Agency Securities

Government National
Mortgage Association
GNMA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Buys FHA, VA, and Farmer's Home Administration insured mortgages from banks and places them into mortgage pools
  • Issues "modified mortgage backedpass through" certificates representing individual interests in the pool
  • Direct-guarantee of the U.S. government
  • Minimum size of an individual GNMA certificate sold to an individual investor is 25K
  • Risks are not subject to default, interest rate risk, and reinvestment rate risk

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Types of Municipal Securities
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
General obligation bonds:Backed by the full faith, credit, andtaxing power of the issuer. GO Bonds are generally considered the safest type of municipal credit.

Revenue bonds:  Backed by a specific source of revenue to which the full faith and credit of the issuer is not pledged.  Because revenue bonds are backed by a single source of funds (like toll roads, hospitals, or nuclear power plants), they have greater credit risk than GO bonds.  As such, they offer at higher yields.

Insurer municipal bonds: The insurers pay timely interest and principal when the issuer is in default.  Municipal bond insurers are AMBAC (American Municipal Bond Assurance Corp.), Berkshire, and Assured Guaranty.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Collateralized Mortgage Obligations
CMO
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Definition:  A special type of bond class in a sequential
pay collateralized mortgage obligation is a CMO. This class of
bond does not receive any interest or principal payments until all other tranches have been completely paid off. In a Z-tranche, the interest that is not paid is accrued and added to the principal. 

CMOs have A to Z tranches with Z being the highest risk and longest duration.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk associated with
Corporate and Municipal Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
DRIP

Default risk:  A creditor may seize the collateral and sell it to recoup the principal.

Reinvestment risk:  As payments are received from an investment, interest rates fall.  When the funds are reinvested, the investor receives a lower yield.

Interest rate risk:  Rising interest rates may cause bond prices to fall.

Purchasing power risk:  Inflation may lower the value of bond interest payments and principal repayment, thereby forcing prices to fall.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk Associated
with Government Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
RIP
No Default or credit risk
 
IP
Zeros are not subject to reinvestment
 
 
NOTE: Treasury securities cannot default

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Price of Convertible Bond
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Convertible bond pricing depends on the following:
  • Interest rates relative to the coupon
  • Value of the issuer's common stock

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Callable Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Definition:  Can be redeemed by the issuer prior to its maturity; usually a premium is paid to the bond owner when the bond is called. 

Cause:  Issuer will call when rates have declined

Call Premium: Cost to the issuer for early redemption

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Puttable Bond
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Definition: Enable bond holder to make the issuer to repurchase thesecurity at specified dates before maturity.

Cause:Issuer must redeem the bond after specific date at par.  If interest rates were to rise after bonds were issued, then there would be a decrease in the price of the bonds.  The investor would exercise the put option. 

Puttable bonds carry lower coupons than non-put bonds.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Liquidation Sequence for Bankrupt
Public Corporation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Sequence: 
 1st   Secured creditors
 2ndUnsecured creditors 
 3rdDebenture bond holders
 4th Preferred stock holders
 5thOwners of common stock holders

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Preferred Stock
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
A hybrid security because it is equity but operates like debt. 
 
The typical purchases of preferred shares is a corporate treasurer with excess funds on hand.  If the treasurer buys bonds, all the interest is taxable.  But if the corporation buys preferred, then 50% of the dividends received are excluded from taxation.

Exclusion is available to corporate investors fordividendsonly.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
American Depositary Receipt
ADR
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
A negotiable certificate issued by a U.S. bank representing a specified number of shares (or one share) in a foreign stock that is traded on a U.S. exchange Instead of buying shares of foreign-based companies in overseas markets; Americans can buy shares in the U.S.  

ADRs do not eliminate the currency and economic risks for the underlying shares in another country. (For example, dividend payments in euros would be converted to U.S. dollars).  ADRs are listed on either the NYSE, AMEX, or Nasdaq.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Exchanged Traded Fund
ETF
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Security representing a basket of stocks or bonds
  • May be an open- or closed-end fund
  • Generally more tax efficient than traditional open-end mutual funds

    Definition: A security that tracks an index, a commodity, or a basket of assets like an index fund, but it trades like a stock on an exchange, thus experiencing price changes throughout the day as it is bought and sold.

    Open-end: May operate in the form of a unit trust or investment company, is traded on stock exchange, and gives investors the opportunity to buy/sell entire portfolio of stocks (bonds) through one vehicle.

    One of the most widely known ETFs is called the SPDR (Spider), which tracks the S&P 500 index.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: ETF Investor Opportunities
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Unlike traditional index mutual funds.  ETFs may be the following: 

  • Sold short
  • Acquired on margin
  • Priced in the moment 
  • Sold without prospectus

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Net Operating Income (NOI) Calculation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Improved land typically is income producing. Income properties include residential rental, commercial, and industrial properties. 

The intrinsic value of a real estate property can be computed using a net operating incomeNOIcomputation. 

Gross rental receipts
+ Non-rental income (laundry, etc.)
Potential gross income (PGI)
-Vacancy and collection losses
-Operating expenses (excludes interest and depreciation)
=Net operating income (NOI)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Real Estate Investment Trust
REIT

 vs. 

 Real Estate Limited Partnership
RELP
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
REIT - porfolio investment and subject to taxation like a stock 
RELP - subject to passive loss rules

REIT - actively traded on securities markets
RELP - generally illiquid

REIT - managed by Board of Directors which are ultimately accountable to their shareholders
RELP - managed by a general partner

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Options

Terms and Concepts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Intrinsic valueis the minimum price the option will command as an option. It is the difference between the market price and the exercise price of the stock.

Exercise price (strike price)is the price at which the stock can be purchased or sold on exercise of the option.

Premiumis the market price of an option.  As the option approaches its expiration date, the market price of the option (the premium) approaches its intrinsic value.

Time premiumis the amount by which the market price of an option exceeds its intrinsic value.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Call Options - Taxability
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
At the time of purchase:  nondeductible capital expenditure

To the writerdue to lapse:  Premium received is short-term gain.  

To the writerdue to exercise:  Premium received is added to sale price (can be long-term gain if the underlying security was held more than 12 months, otherwise it is short-term gain). 
 
To the holderif the option is not exercised: The option is considered sold (it expires), and it is a short-term loss.  The option term is 9 months or less.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Warrants vs. Call Options
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Warrants are issued by corporations whereas calls are created by individuals.

  • Warrants typically have maturities of several years. 

  • Warrant terms are not standardized; call options are standardized.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Hedging with
Futures Contracts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Long commodity position:  If a farmer is long a commodity (for example, corn), he needs a short hedge and will sell a futures contract.

Short commoditiy position:  If Kellogg is short a commodity (for example, corn), Kellogg needs a long hedge and will buy a futures contract.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Short Selling
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Short sellers must have a margin account to sell short.
  • The net proceeds from a short sale, plus the required margin, are held by the broker.  No funds immediately received by the short seller.
  • There is no time limit on a short sale. 
  • Dividends declared on any stock sold short must be covered by the short seller.
NOTE:  The loss is theoretically unlimited while the profit is limited (cannot go below zero).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Reg D
Accredited vs. Non-accredited
Investor
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Accredited (unlimited 1, 2, 3)
1.Net worth of $1,000,000 (not including personal residence)
2.Individual with an annual income of $200,000
3.Couple with a joint income of $300,000
 
Non-Accredited
1.Sold to a maximum of 35 investors
2.Must use a purchaser representative if not "sophisticated"

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Systematic Risk
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
This part of the risk is inescapable because no matter how well an investor diversifies, the risk of the overall market cannot be avoided.

Also known asnon-diversifiable risk or total risk

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Types of Systematic Risk (Nondiversifiable)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
"P R I M E"

Purchasing power risk: loss of purchasing power through inflation

Reinvestment rate risk: risk that proceeds available for reinvestment must be reinvested at a lower interest rate than the instrument that generated the proceeds

Interest rate risk: risk that a change in interest rates will cause the market value of the fixed income security to fall

Market risk: risk of the overall market

Exchange rate risk: risk associated with changes in the value of currency

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Unsystematic Risk 
(Diversifiable)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Known asdiversifiable risk,may also be referred to in some reference books asnon-systematic risk

  • Business risk: Refers to the nature of the firm's operation (ie: possibility of loss due to new technology)
  • Financial risk: Refers to how the firm finances its assets (ie: possibility of loss due to heavy debt financing)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Foreign Currency Exchange

Devaluation
vs.
Revaluation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Devaluation:lowering of the value of a currency relative to the currencies of other nations; can also result from a rise in value of other currencies relative to the currency of a particular country

Revaluation:generally means an increase in the currency's value

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Portfolio Diversification
 
Perfectly Positive Correlated
vs.
Perfectly Negative Correlated
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Positively: Securites have a value of +1.0.  The securities move exactly together.  There is no reduction of portfolio risk.

Negatively:  Securites have a value of -1.0.  The securities move exactly opposite, risk is virtually eliminated.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Coefficient of Determination R2
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
What is R2?
The square of the correlation coefficient measuring the proportion of the variation in one variable explained by the movement of the other variable (often the market).

How is R2used on the exam?
It describes the percentage of a fund's movement that is explained by the movements in the S&P 500.  Index funds/diversified funds based on the S&P 500 will have R2 very close to 100%, while sector funds (not diversified) will have very low R2(typically 5%-25%).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Coefficient of Variation
CV
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Coefficient of Variation expresses relative risk adjusted returns of different investments. Calculated using the standard deviation divided by the average or mean return.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Expressing Investment Risk
 
Standard Deviation
vs.
Beta
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Standard Deviation:measures variability of returns used in a nondiversfied portfolio and is a measure of total risk

Beta: measures volatility of returns in a diversified portfolio and is a measure of systematic risk

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Risk-Adjusted Return
CardContent.FlashCardBack: To standardize for risk, one must divide an individual fund's realized return by its beta coefficient.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Time-Weighted Return
Geometric Mean

vs.

Dollar-Weighted Return
Internal Rate of Return
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Time Weighted:portfolio accounting method that measures investment performance (income and price changes) as a percentage of capital at work thus eliminating the effects of additions and withdrawals

Dollar Weighted:  portfolio accounting method that measures changes in total dollar value, treating additions and withdrawals of capital as part of the return along with income and capital gains and losses

CardContent.FlashCardFront: "Real" vs. Nominal Return
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Real: the inflation adjusted interest rate
The "real" rate is defined as the nominal rate of return adjusted for inflation.  This is important for long-term goals.

Nominal: actual returns not adjusted for inflation

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Holding Period Return
HPR
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Thetotal return(income plus price appreciation and dividends less margin interest) over the entire perioddivided by the price of the investment(out-of-pocket).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Internal Rate of Return
IRR
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
IRR: discount rate at which the present value of future cash flows equals the cost of the investment

  • When the NPV of the cashflow is zero, the discount rate being used is the IRR.
  • When the IRR is greater than the required return, the investment is acceptable.
NOTE:  This is used when investment produces uneven cash flows.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Yield to Maturity
YTM
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
YTM:   promised compounded total return an investor will receive from a bond at the rate equal to the computed YTM

  • Takes into account both the market price of the bond as well as any capital gains or losses on the bond if held to maturity as well as coupon payments
  • When calculating YTM,alwaysuse semiannual compounding (evenwith zero coupon bonds)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Yield to Call
YTC
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
YTC: presumes that the bond will be redeemed by the issuer at the firstcalldate in the indenture agreement

  • Uses the same calculation as YTMexceptthat the principal value at maturity is replaced by thecallprice, and the maturity date is replaced by the firstcalldate

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Municipal Securities

Taxable Equivalent Yield
TEY
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
To make the returns on municipal bonds comparable to those of taxable bonds, theTEYcan be calculated.

Taxable equivalent yield (TEY) = Tax exempt yield
                                               1 - Marginal tax rate

OR

Taxable equivalent yield (TEY) x (1-marginal tax rate)
=
Tax exempt yield

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Bond Duration
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
t= years to maturity (Remember duration and maturity are positively related.)

c= annual coupon (Remember duration isinversely related to coupon rate.)

y= YTM, the current yield on comparative bonds (Duration isinversely related.)

Remember - Coupon and yield areinterest rates (inversely related).

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Immunization
CardContent.FlashCardBack: A passive investment strategy to safeguard a bond portfolio against interest rate volatility.  A portfolio is immunized if the average duration of the portfolio is equal to a pre-selected time horizon for the financial need.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Zero Coupon Bonds
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Duration equal to their maturities 

  • No coupon interest, yet produces "phantom" income

  • No reinvestment rate risk

  • Sold at deep discounts to par

  • Fluctuate more than coupon bonds with same maturities

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Using Duration to Manage Bond Portfolios
CardContent.FlashCardBack: If interest rates are expected to rise, shorten duration (interest rates up- shorten duration -UPS -UPfor up andSfor shorten).  Buy high coupon bonds with short maturities.  If interest rates are expected to fall, lengthen duration.  Buy low coupon bonds with long maturities (interest rates fall -lengthen duration -FALLEN - FALfor fall andLENfor lengthen).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Conclusions to Fluctuations in
Bond Prices
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• The smaller the coupon, the greater the relative price fluctuation

  • The longer the term to maturity, the greater the relative price fluctuation

  • The lower the market interest rate, the greater the relative price fluctuation

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Dividend Discount Model
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If the market lowers therequired rate of returnfor a stock, the value of the common stock will rise.
  • If investors expect that growth in dividends will be higher as a result of favorable development for the firm, the value of the common stock will rise.
  • The opposite (higherrequired rate of returnor lower dividends) lowers the value of the common stock.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Return on Equity
ROE

Dividend Payout Ratio
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
ROE     =   Earnings available for common (EPS)
                   Common equity (net worth or book value)

Dividend payout ratio  =        Common dividends paid
                                     Earnings available for common (EPS)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Efficient Frontier
(Markowitz)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Efficient frontierseeks thehighestreturn for any given level of risk or the lowest risk for any given level of return.  Any point on the efficient frontier is efficient (attainable). 

Inefficient (attainable)All points (those below the efficient frontier) arefeasiblebut are inefficient.  They are not on the efficient frontier.

Not feasible (unattainable)  Portfolios above the boundary (the efficient frontier) are not feasible because they cannot provide high return with low risk for any period of time under the model.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Security Market Line
SML
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Second component of the CAPM 
  • Specifies relationship between risk and return for the individual asset.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Three Types of
Efficient Market Hypothesis

EMH
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Strong Form:Asserts that stock prices fully reflect all information,public and private.  Not even access to inside information can be expected to result in superior investment performance over time. Neither fundamental analysis nor technical analysiscan produce superior results over time on a risk-adjusted basis.

Semi-Strong Form:  Asserts that allpublicly known informationis reflected in stock prices. Neither technical analysis nor fundamental analysiscan produce superior results over time on a risk-adjusted basis.  Only an investor with access toinside informationmay consistently achieve superior results. (Such access is illegal.)

Weak Form:Suggests historical price data is already reflected in current stock prices and is of no value in predicting future price changes.Technical analysiswill not produce superior results. Fundamental analysis may produce superior results, over the short term.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Active Investment Strategies
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Fundamental analysis methods
  • Technical analysis methods
  • Tactical asset allocation (market timing)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Passive Investment Strategies
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Buy & hold (EMH)
  • Dollar cost averaging
  • Index investing
  • Strategic asset allocation (revised every few years)
  • Core-Satellite

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Tax Basis of Mutual Fund
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• First-in, first-out method treats shares acquired first as being sold first.
  • Specific ID requires the seller to identify the shares of the fund that are sold. Specific ID allows the investor to create gain, neutralize gain, or create a loss (most flexible).
  • Average cost method allows investor to divide the total cost of all shares held by the number of shares held.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk Adjusted
Measures of Performance

Sharpe Ratio
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
When to use:

1st key: 
Look for low R2(less than 60) or nondiversified portfolio

2nd key:
Look for highest Sharpe number

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk Adjusted Measures of
Performance

Jensen (alpha)/Treynor Ratio
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
When to use:

1st key: 
Look for high R2(60+) or diversified portfolio

2nd key:
Look for highest positive alpha
If no alpha given, then look for the highest Treynor number

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Maintenance Margin Call
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The formula for calculating when an investor will receive a margin call is the following:

  1 - Initial margin percentage   x   Purchase price of stock
1 - Maintenance margin percentage

Shortcut:
2/3 of purchase price if minimum maintenance is 25%.  If minimum maintenance is 30%, take 2/3 and choose next highest number.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk Tolerant
Investor Characteristics
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• High debt ratios
  • Small amounts of insurance
  • Propensity to change jobs/locations
  • Makes quick decisions
  • High level of wealth for age
  • Optimistic outlook
  • Handles stress well
  • Investment experience

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Risk Adverse
Investor Characteristics
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• No debt
  • High amounts of insurance
  • Stable employment
  • Deliberate thought process
  • Low level of wealth for age
  • Pessimistic outlook
  • Handles stress poorly
  • Little investment experience

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Key Inclusions that
Make Up Gross Income (1040)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Wages
  • Ordinary dividends
  • Business income
  • Capital gains and losses
  • IRA distributions
  • Real estate income
  • Alimony received
  • Taxable Social Security
  • Taxable interest

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Adjustments or Deductions for
Adjusted Gross Income
AGI

(above the line)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Adjustments or Deductions for Adjusted Gross IncomeAGIis total income (or gross income) less adjustments to income.  The main adjustments or deductions to income are the following: 

  • IRA contributions (if eligible)
  • Self-employment tax* 
  • Self-employment health insurance (100%)
  • Keogh or SEP
  • Alimony paid 

*Self employment income x .07065 or 1/2 of .1413
There are additional adjustments or deductions but they are not tested.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Schedule A
Itemized Deductions

Deductions from AGI
(below the line)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Medical, dental, and LTC (exceeding 7.5% of AGI)
  • Casualty and theft losses (beginning in 2018, must be due to declared Presidentially declared disaster)
  • Real estate taxes* ($10,000 cap with state and local SALT)
  • Investment interest expense
  • Home mortgage interest* ($750,000 cap)
  • No $100,000 home equity deduction
  • State and local taxes / personal property tax (up to $10,000 cap combined) 
  • Charitable gifts*

* See charitable giving rules

CardContent.FlashCardFront: What Qualifies as Investment Income to take a deduction
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Investment interest (margin) deduction is limited to net investment income. Income includes: 
  • Interest
  • Dividends (not qualified)
  • Royalty income
  • Short term gain

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Casualty Losses
Calculation of the deductible loss
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Calculation: 
First:
Use the lesser of basis or FMV
Second:
Subtract any insurance coverage
Third:
Subtract $100 (floor)
Fourth:
Subtract 10% of AGI*
*Subject to 10% rule phaseout

NOTE: Only apply to Presidentially declared disasters.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Deducting Entertainment Expenses
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Office party expense: 100% deductible 2018
  • Employee travel meals: 50% deductible
  • Meals provided for convenience of the employer: 50% 
  • Entertaining expenses:not deductible

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Kiddie Tax
Income Tax
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Applies to unearned income of children who have not attained age 24 by year-end; taxed at trust tax brackets
  • Over $2,100 (2018) unearned investment income
  • Child gets $1,050 (2018) standard deduction
  • Additional $1,050 (2018) taxed at child's tax rate (10%)
  • Income beyond $2,100 is taxed at trust rates below
    • under $2,550 = 10%
    • $2,550 - $9,150 = $255 + 24% over $2,550
    • $9,150 - $12,500 = $1,839 + 35% over $9,150
    • over $12,500 = $3.012 + 37% over $12,500

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Self-Employment Income
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Self-employment income includes: 
  • Net Schedule C income
  • General partnership income (K-1 income)
  • Board of Directors fees
  • Part-time earnings (1099) or independent contractor

Does NOT include the following.

  • Wages from an S corp
  • K-1 distributions from an S corp
  • Real estate income or rents received
  • Gains from property, securities, or commodities
  • Dividends or interest from investments

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Self-Employment
Tax Calculation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
To calculate the self-employment tax use the shortcut:
Multiply total net self-employment income by 14.13% and round up

CardContent.FlashCardFront: FICA Tax
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
There are two FICA tax components
  • 6.2% up to $128,400 (2018)
  • 1.45% unlimited Medicare
These are paid by both the employee and the employer.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Tax Credits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Credit for child & dependent care expenses (non-refundable)
  • Child tax credit - phaseout at $400,000 MAGI for married filing jointly
  • Adoption credit (non-refundable)
  • Elderly and disabled credit (non-refundable)
  • Foreign tax credit (non-refundable)
  • Earned income credit (refundable)

NOTE: Refundable credits are recoverable regardless of your tax liability even if you owe no taxes.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Sources of
Federal Tax Law/Authority
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Internal Revenue Code:primary source of all tax law

  • Treasury regulations:authority but not law

  • Revenue rulings and Revenue procedures:  administrative interpretation/may be cited

  • Congressional Committee reports:indicate the intent of Congress/may not be cited

  • Private letter rulings: apply to a specific taxpayer

  • Judical sources: court decisions interpret tax law

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Dates for Paying Estimated Taxes
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Also called quarterly estimates but are not actually calendar quarters
  • April 15 (1st payment)
  • June 15 (ADD 2 months to April)
  • September 15 (ADD 3 months to June)
  • January 15 (ADD 4 months to September)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: IRS Penalties
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Negligence: Penalty is 20% of the portion of the underpayment attributed to negligence.

Civil Fraud: Penalty is 75% of the portion of the tax underpayment attributable.

Failure to file: Penalty is 5% of the tax due per month, with a maximum of 25%.

Failure to PAY: Penalty is 0.5% per month the tax is unpaid, with a maximum of 25% (pay-point).

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Avoiding the Federal Withholding Tax Underpayment Penalty
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
To avoid, pay thelesserof the following.

1.

90% of the current year's tax liability

2.

100% of the prior year's tax liability (or 110% if the 2017 adjusted gross income exceeded $150,000)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Net Operating Losses
NOL
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Loss arising after January 1, 2018 will no longer allow 2 year look back.
  • The loss may be carried forward indefinitely.  However, starting 1/1/2018 it will be limited to 80% of taxable income.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Advantage of a Regular C Corporation
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Advantages
  • Separate tax entity
  • Sale of stock to unlimited number of investors
  • Dividend-received deduction (70%/80%/100% rule)
  • Limited liability 
  • Continuity of life

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Section 1244
Small Business Stock Election
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The tax treatment is available for the first $1 million of stock.

Individuals who realize a loss on 1244 stock may deduct a limited portion of loss as ordinary, rather than capital loss.  Married individuals filing jointly are limited to an annual $100,000 ordinary deduction ($50,000 single).  Any loss in excess of these limits retains its character as a capital loss.  Section 1244 has no downside.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Personal Service businesses that operate as 
a regular Corporation
PSC
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
HHealth
AAccounting, Architectural, Artists
LLaw
EEngineering

Not CFP®professionals or Insurance Agents

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Taxation of
Personal Service Corporation
PSC
CardContent.FlashCardBack: A closely held C corporation that is owned by certain individuals who perform services is denied the progressivity of corporate rate schedule.  Any income retained by a PSC is taxed at a flat 21%.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
S Corporation
 
Eligibility
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• The number of shareholders is limited to 100.

  • The corporation can have only a single class of outstanding common stock (no preferred), but the common stock can be voting or non-voting.

  • Must be a domestic corporation

  • Only individuals, estates, and certain trusts may be shareholders.  NOTE:  Nonresident aliens (persons who are neither citizens nor permanent residents of the U.S.) cannot be shareholders.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Conduit Entities
General Partnerships
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Partnership is an unincorporated association of two or more persons to conduct business as co-owners.  A partnership must file a tax return (Form 1065), but it is for information purposes only.  Each partner includes in his/her return the distributed share of the partnership income or loss items.

Losses up to basis: Basis equals cash contributed by the partner, direct loans made to the partnership by the partner, and loans made to the partnership - not the partner (share of partnership debt for which the partner may ultimately be held responsible) known as recourse loans.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Pass through Entities
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Partnerships, S corporations, LLCs, and sole proprieterships
  • Can claim 20% deduction on earnings subject to special rule restrictions

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Conduit Entities
S Corporations
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Losses up to basis: Basis equals cash contributed by the shareholder plus direct loans made by the shareholder to the S corporation.

NOTE:  When an S corp incurs debt, shareholders typically do not have personal liability for the debt.  Therefore, S corporation debt is NOT included in the shareholders' basis.  However, even if the shareholders have personally guaranteed the debt, the debt doesnotincrease the shareholders' basis.  S corp basis does NOT include bank loans even if the owner personally guarantees the debt.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Amortization
Section 197
CardContent.FlashCardBack: A business may own a variety of assets with no physical substance.  However, the assets represent a valuable property right or economic attribute, for example, goodwill.  The tax basis is such that intangible assets may be recoverable under some type of amortization method. Intangibles are amortized under a tax section called Section 197 intangibles.  The recovery method is similiar to straight-line depreciation.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Property Classes
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
5 year Computers,Autos, and light dutyTrucks (1245property)

7 year Office equipment except computers (1245property)

27½ year Residential rental property (1250property)

39 yearNon-residential real property (1250property)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Like Kind Exchange
Boot / Gain Recognized
under Section 1031

 
       Can a business do a like kind             exchanges using personal property      assets for personal property assets
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1. The easiest answer to boot and recognized gain question(s) is when there isno boot received, the recognized gainiszero.

  2. Whenboot is received, you should choose the answer thatrecognized gain is the boot received. It has a high probability of being right.  

    No, 1031 is only for real estate exchanges.  These still can contain boot assets.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Netting Capital Gains & Losses
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Three step process:
  1. ST capital gains and ST losses are netted.
    LT capital gains and LT losses are netted.

  2. If a gain and a loss remain, they are again netted.
     
  3. If a loss remains after netting capital gains and losses, only $3,000 of net losses can be used to offset ordinary income.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Capital Gains 

Tax Rates
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Long-term gains (heldmorethan 12 months) are subject to rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% based on taxable income (varies depending on filing). 

  • Short-term gains are taxed at ordinary income rates.

  • Long-term collectible gains are subject to a tax rate of 28%.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Sale of Personal Residence
Exemption

 Section 121
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Section 121 exemption on the sale of residence:
  • $250K (single) and $500K (married filing jointly) of gain from sale is tax-free if lived in home for two out of the last five years.

  • Exception available - If taxpayer lives in the residencelessthan two years and moves because of a new job, for health reasons, etc., he/she receives the prorated amount.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: AMT Preference Items
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Preference items

  • Intangible drilling costs (IDC)
  • Private-activity municipal bond
  • Oil & gas percentage depletion - but not cost depletion
  • Depreciation (ACRS/MACRS) - but not straight-line

CardContent.FlashCardFront: AMT Add Back Items
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
AMT add back items
  • Incentive stock option - bargain element
  • Property and state/local income taxes
  • Miscellaneous deductions - specifically financial advisor fees
  • Homeequityinterest

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Minimizing or Eliminating
AMT
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• When accelerating receipt of taxable income or deferring the payment of property taxes, state income taxes, deductible medical expenses, or charitable giving, the regular tax (1040) may exceed the AMT payable(more taxable income)
  • Deferring exercise of incentive stock options to a later dateordisqualifying the ISO so that it becomes NQSO (subject to ordinary tax)
  • Purchasing public purpose muni bonds instead of private purpose bonds

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Phantom Income
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Phantom income comes from the following: 

Insurance: Lapse of policy loan, Section 162 life/disability

Investments: Zero/Strip income, TIPS, declared but not paid dividends

Tax: K-1 income from LP/FLP, recapture

Retirement: NUA, 20% withholding plan distributions, secular trust

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Two Kinds of Passive Activities
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1. Rental and royalty income
  2. Businesses in which the taxpayer does not materially participate like:
  • Limited partnerships (with some exceptions)
  • Partnership, S corporations (with some exceptions), and limited liability companies in which the taxpayer does notmateriallyparticipate

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Real Estate Exceptions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Material Participation
Taxpayer will be treated as materially participating in an activity only if the taxpayer is involved in the operation of the activity on a regular, continuous, and substantial basis.  Generally, no limited partner in a limited partnership is treated as materially participating in the partnership's activity.

Active Participation
Active participation is a lesser standard than material participation.  It merely requiresbona fideinvolvement in management decisions.  A limited partner may never be an active participant.  To qualify, the taxpayer must own at least a 10% interest in the property.  The $25,000 loss for active participation in real estate is phased out between $100,000 and $150,000 AGI.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Low-income Housing

Housing Credit
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Low-income housing programs that are held as passive activity may generate a deduction-equivalent tax credit up to $25,000. There is no phase-out.

The low income housing credit is allowed annually over a ten-year "credit period".  The depreciation is straight-line over 27.5 years.

How does the credit work?
For example, you multiply 35% by $25,000 to get a credit of $8,750.
NOTE:  Because there is no phase-out, it produces a higher credit.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Alimony Requirements
for Deductibility
2018
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Alimony is deductible by payor and taxable to payee if the following requirements are met:

  • The taxpayers cannot file a joint tax return or live together at the time of payment.
  • Payments must be made in cash.
  • Payments must be received by or for the benefit of the payee spouse (not child support).
  • The payments cannot extend beyond the death of the recipient spouse.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Child Support
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Payments are nontaxable to the payee and nondeductible by the payor.
  • Any amount tied to a contingency or occurrence of an event relating to a child is considered to be child support and not alimony.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Charitable Contributions
Public vs. Private
"charities"
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Public - 50 % organizations

  • All churches, schools, and hospitals
  • All organizations organized and operated for charitable, religious, educational, or literary purposes or for the prevention of cruelty to children or animals (United Way, Red Cross, Humane Society, etc.)

Private - 30 % organizations

  • Private non-operating foundations
  • War veterans' organizations
  • Fraternal orders

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Charitable Income
Tax Deduction
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1. Calculate the maximium deductible - can be 60% AGI for cash or 50% AGI for non-cash contribution
  2. Calculate the eligible amounts given to 50% organizations (public charities) such as all churches, schools, hospitals, and organizations such as the United Way, Red Cross, Humane Society, etc.
  3. Calculate the eligible amounts given to 30% organizations (privated charities) such as private non-operating foundations, war veteran groups, and fraternal orders

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Charitable Giving
Types of property - 50% charities
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Long-term appreciated property - using FMV deduct up to 30% of AGI or valued at basis to 60% of AGI. 

  • Use-unrelated property, ST capital gain property - using basis deduct up to 50% of AGI

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Miscellaneous Deductions
Schedule A
subject to 2% of AGI
 
 
(also called Tier II deductions)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Fees to investment counselors
  • Tax advice and preparation fees
  • Hobby losses
  • Unreimbursed employee business expense
  • Employee home office expense

They are aggregated and then 2% of AGI is subtracted.
