CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Workers not Covered
by Social Security
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Coverage - Nearly every worker is covered under OASDI.  Employment categories not covered by Social Security include the following:

A.Federal employees who have been continuously employed since before 1984
B.Some Americans working abroad
C.Student nurses and students working for a college or college club
D.Railroad employees
E.A child, under age 18, who is employed by a parent in an unincorporated business
F.Ministers, members of religious orders, and Christian Science practitioners if they claim an exemption
G.Members of tribal councils

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security
Fully Insured Worker
Eligibility and Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• A worker is entitled to disability benefits if he/she is under age 65 and has been disabled for 12 months, is expected to be disabled for at least 12 months, or has a disability which is expected to result in death and has completed a 5-month waiting period.
  • A retired insured worker age 62 or over (for Social Security payments) is entitled to retirement benefits.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security - Spouse's
Eligibility and Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• The spouse of aretired or disabled workerqualifies:
    for Social Security payments if he/she
    • is age 62 or over or
    • has a child in care under age 16 or
    • has a child age 16 and over and disabled.
  • Thesurviving spouse(including a surviving divorced spouse) or adeceasedinsured worker qualifies for Social Security payments if the widow(er) is age 60 or over
  • Thesurviving spouseof adeceasedinsured worker, regardless of age, qualifies for Social Security payments if caring for an entitled child of the deceased who is either under age 16 or disabled before age 22.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security - Dependent/Child
Eligibility and Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Thesurviving dependent,unmarried child of adeceased or disabledinsured worker, qualifies for Social Security payments if the child is:

  • under 19 and a full-time elementary or secondary school student or
  • age 18 or over but has a disability which began before age 22.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security

Retirement Benefits and
Working After Retirement
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
If born January 2, 1943 through January 1955

  • Full retirement age for retirement insurance benefits is 66
  • Working at full retirement age or older - you will keep all benefits
  • If younger than full retirement age - limited income if receiving full Social Security benefits
  • If younger than full retirement age during all of 2018 - deduct $1 from benefits for each $2 earned above $17,040 
  • Ifreach full retirement age during 2018  Deduct $1 from benefits for each $3 earned above $45,360 until the month one reaches full retirement age (at age 66 currently)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security Taxation  

Provisional Income
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Must include muni bond income to calculate MAGI
  • If income (MAGI) plus ½ of social security benefits is
    1.Above 25K for a single taxpayer, then 50% of the total social security is included in income.
    2.Above 44K for married filing jointly, then 85% of the total social security is included in income.
  • Numbers are not adjusted for inflation, and not provided for the exam.
Provisional income is AGI plus ½ Social Security income plus tax-exempt interest (MAGI)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Social Security
Disability Benefits
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
A worker is entitled to disability benefits if he/she:

  • is insured for disability benefits, is under age 65,
  • has been disabled for 12 months, is expected to be disabled for at least 12 months, or suffered from a disability which is expected to result in death,
  • has filed for disability benefits, and completed a 5-month waiting period.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Characteristics of
Qualifed Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• May not discriminate
  • Must satisfy ERISA requirements
  • Immediate tax deduction for contribution (although employee may not be vested)
  • Earnings accrue tax deferred until distribution
  • Distributions are taxable at ordinary tax rates (exception: 10-year averaging and NUA under Stock Bonus & ESOPs)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Types of Qualified Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Defined Benefit
  • Cash Balance
  • Money Purchase
  • Target Benefit
  • Profit-Sharing
  • Profit-Sharing 401(k)
  • Stock Bonus
  • ESOP (cannotbe integrated with Social Security)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Features of Qualified Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Subject to ERISA 
  • Has administration cost
  • Exempt from creditors
  • Can be integrated with Social Security (except ESOP plans)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Money Purchase
Pension Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Up to 25% employer deduction
  • Fixed contributions - need stable cash flow
  • Maximum annual contributionlesserof 100% of salary or $55K(2018)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Target Benefit Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Up to 25% employer deduction
  • Fixed contributions - need stable cash flow
  • Maximum annual contributionlesserof 100% of salary or $55K(2018)
  • Favors older workersbecause actuary determines contribution base considering employee's age.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Profit Sharing Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Up to 25% employer deduction
  • Flexible contributions(must be recurring and substantial)
  • Maximum annual contributionlesser of 100% of salary or $55K(2018)
  • Can have 401(k) provisions
  • SIMPLE 401(k) exempt from creditors

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Section 401(k) Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Provision in a profit sharing or stock bonus plan that allows plan participants to defer salary into the plan (elective)
  • Max $18,500(2018) deferral for participants under 50 (subject to FICA)
  • Additional $6,000 (2018)catch-up for age 50 and over

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Solo 401(k)
Uni-401(k)
Uni-K
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Not subject to coverage testing.
  • Not subject to nondiscrimination rules necessary for the typical 401(k) plan
  • Plan allows the elective deferral up to $18,500 plus the employer contribution with a cap of $55K(2018).
  • Catch-up of $6,000 is allowed if participant's age is 50 or older.
  • Corporate plan limitations are 25% of the owner's compensation to a maximum of $55K(2018)(no catch-up).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Stock Bonus
and
Employee Stock Ownership Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Up to 25% employer deduction
  • Flexible contributions
  • Maximum annual contributionlesserof 100% of salary or $55K(2018)
  • 100% of contribution can be invested  in company stock.
  • ESOP cannot be integrated with Social Security or cross-tested.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Section 415
Annual Additions Limit
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Lesser of 100% of compensation or $55K(2018)

  • Includes employer contributions, employee salary reductions (elective deferrals),and plan forfeitures

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Defined Benefit 
Pension Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Contributions are actuarially determined
  • Favorsolderemployee/owner (50+)
  • Certain retirement benefit; Max $220K (2018)
    Meet a specific retirement objective
  • Company must have very stable cash flow
  • Past service credits allowed
  • Forfeitures MUST be applied to reduce employer contributions
  • PBGC insured (along with Cash Balance plan)

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Cash Balance Pension Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Cash Balance plans provide for annual employer contributions at a specified rate to hypothetical individual accounts that are set up for each plan participant.
  • Employer guarantees not only the contribution level but also a minimum rate of return on each participant's account. 
  • Plan works somewhat like a money purchase plan, but money purchase plans do not involve employer guarantees of rate of return.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Defined Benefit Type Plan
412 i [412(e)3]
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Defined benefit
  • Funded entirely with insurance products
  • Exempt from typcial ERISA minimum funding standard

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Simplified Employee Pension
SEP IRA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Not a qualified plan
  • NO salary deferrals - employer contributions only
  • Up to 25% contribution for owner (W-2) / treated like Keogh contributions for self-employed
  • Maximum of $55K(2018)
  • Account immediately vested
  • Can be integrated with Social Security
  • Special eligibility: 21+ years old, paid at least $600 -2018, and worked 3 of the 5 prior years

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Simple IRA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Not a qualified plan
  • Fewer than 100 employees
  • Employer cannot maintain any other plan
  • Participants fully vested
  • Easy to administer and funded by employee salary reductions and an employer match
  • Distributions are the same as IRA rules except the 10% penalty is increased to 25% during first two years of participation

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Tax-deferred Annuity (TDA)/Tax -
sheltered Annuity (TSA) /403(b)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• For 501(c)(3) organizations and public schools
  • Subject to some ERISA rules only if employer contributes
  • Salary reduction limit up to (plus $6,000 catch-up if so $18,500(2018)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Section 457
Deferred Compensation Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Nonqualified deferred compensation plans of governmental agencies and non-church controlled tax exempt organizations
  • Deferral limited to $18,500(2018) or 100% of compensation
  • Catch-up of $6,000(2018) allowed for those aged 50 and overONLYfor governmental plans
  • Salary deferralsNOTaggregated with other plans (401k, etc.)
  • Nongovernmental plans canONLYbe rolled into another 457 plan
*Limited to highly compensated employees also called "top hat" plan

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Qualified Plans
Age and Service Rules

(eligibility)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Max age and service are age 21 and one year of service (21-and-one-rule).
  • Special provision allows up to 2-year service requirement, BUT then employee is immediately vested (2-year/100%).
  • Year of service is 1,000 hours (can include vacations, holidays, and sick days).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Qualified Plan
Coverage Requirements

Ratio and Average Benefit Test
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Ratio: percentage test:
Plan must cover a percentage of non-highly compensated employees (NHCEs) that is at least 70% of the percentage of highly compensated employees (HCEs) covered.  If this test is failed, then the next test must be passed.

Average benefit test:
Average benefits for all non-highly compensated employees (NHCEs) must be at least 70% of that for highly compensated employees (HCEs).

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Vesting Schedules
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Fast:  Top-heavy Plans / All DC Plans
  • 3-year cliff or 2-6 year graded or 100% vested after 2 years

Slow:  Non-top-heavy / DB plans only

  • 5-year cliff or 3-7 year graded or 100% vested after 2 years

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Attribution Rules
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Attribution rules can affect who is akey, or highly-compensated, employee(for the >5% ownership rule). If you are 1) an employee and 2) thespouse,parent, child, or grandparent of an individual who is a 5% owner, you aredeemed to be a 5% owner yourself.  (Only a parent, not a grandparent, is deemed to own stock for children under age 21.) NOTE: A brother or sister does not affect the attribution rules.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Controlled Groups
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Controlled group status is used to determine related employers and participation tests.
  • Parent - subsidiary 
  • Brother - Sister
  • Affiliated service group
  • Employee leasing

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Plans that can be integrated
vs.
Plans that cannot be integrated
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Plans that can be integrated with Social Security
Defined Benefit, Cash Balance, Money Purchase, Target Benefit, Profit Sharing, Stock Bonus and SEP

Safe harbor 401(k) and 401(k) match only - difficult without profit-sharing contribution

Plans that cannot be integrated with Social Security
ESOP, SIMPLE and 401(k) SIMPLE

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Multiple Plans 
Elective Deferrals
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Elective deferrals -more than one employer - 2018

Elective deferrals to multiple plans are alwaysaggregated.

2018
401(k)/403(b)/SIMPLE*/SARSEP $18,500 plus catch up ($6,000)
SIMPLE and other SIMPLE$12,500 plus catch up ($3,000)

*NOTE: The SIMPLE is still limited to 12,500 with 3,000 catch-up.
457 plans are NOT part of aggregated amounts.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Defined Contribution Limits
for Keogh/SEP
Plans for Self-Employed
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Shortcut for 15% and 25% plans

  • Multiply by 12.12% for 15% contribution
  • Multiply by 18.59% for 25% contribution
NOTE: Normal testing percentages, if tested.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Qualified Plan
Early (age 59 1/2) - QP 10% Tax Penalty Exceptions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Death
  • Disability
  • Substantially equal periodic payments following separation from service
  • Distribution following separation from service at age 55
  • Distribution in accordance with QDRO (to any alternative payee)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Required Beginning Date
RBD

for
IRAs / SEPs / SARSEPs / SIMPLEs
CardContent.FlashCardBack: The required beginning date is April 1st of the year following the year in which the covered individual attained age 70½.   Subsequent distributions must be made by December 31st of each year thereafter.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Required Beginning DateRBD
for
Qualified plans/403(b) plans/457 Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The required beginning date,with the exception of 5% owners,is the later of April 1st following the year in which the individual attained 70½ orretired.Subsequent distributions must be made by December 31st of each year thereafter.
 
5% owner RBD is the same as IRA/SEP RBD.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Life Insurance as a
Qualified Funding Vehicle
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
According to the Treasury Regulations, life insurance benefits must be merely "incidental" to the primary purpose of the plan.  If the amount of insurance meets either of the following tests,it is considered incidental.
  1. The aggregate premiums paid for a participant's insured death benefit are less than the following percentages of the plan cost for that participant:
    Ordinary Life Insurance50%;Term Insurance25%;
    Universal Life25%
  2. Defined benefit plans typically use the "100 times" limit.  The participant's insured death benefit must be no more than100 times the expected monthly benefit.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
IRA
Deductibility Keys
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If neither spouse (or single person) is an active participant in an employer plan, the IRA is deductible.  Employer plans that affect participant status include almost all plans EXCEPT for 457 plans.
  • If one spouse is an active participant, the other spouse (not active) can do a deductible IRA if combined AGI is less than $189K-199K (2018).
  • If both spouses are active, AGI limits apply - $63-73K (single) and $101-121K (married) (2018).

NOTE:  Activity that results in active status:  annual additions (including forfeitures) to a DC account or benefits accrued to a DB plan

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
IRA Exceptions to 10% Penalty
for Early Distributions
before Age 59½
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Death
  • Substantially equal payments
  • Disability
  • First home expense up to $10,000
  • Qualified education expense
  • Medical expense greater than 10% of AGI
  • Distribution used to pay insurance premium after separation from employment (must have received unemployment compensation for 12 weeks)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Roth IRA
Required Minimum Distributions
(after owner's death)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Distributed within five years of owner's death or
  • Distributed over the life expectancy of the designated beneficiary with distributions commencing prior to the end of the calendar year following death
  • Where sole beneficiary is owner's surviving spouse, the spouse may delay distributions until the Roth owner would have reached age 70½ or may treat the Roth as his or her own (roll it to his/her Roth).

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Roth IRA
Ordering Rules for Distributions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1. Any contributions (not conversions) are withdrawn first.
  2. Conversions are withdrawn second.
  3. Earnings are withdrawn last.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
AGI Limits for
Roth IRA Contributions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Individuals

phased out between $120K-135K

Married filing jointly

phased out between $189K-199K

Married filing separately

phased out between $0 and $10K*

All numbers are for2018.
*almost impossible

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Elective Deferred Limits
for Roth Plans
401(k)/403(b)/457(b)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Maximum elective deferral amount is $18,500 plus $6,000 catch-up (if age 50 by 12/31 of deferral year). 
  • Employer contributions (including matching contributions) go into traditional 401(k) pre-tax accounts.
  • No income restrictions associated with Roth 401(k), 403(b), or 457(b) accounts.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Net Unrealized Appreciation
NUA

(Employer Stock)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
NUA Example
Stock is contributed to the retirement plan with a basis of $20,000. Stock is distributed at retirement with a market value of $200,000.  The NUA, $180,000, is not taxable until the employee sells the stock, but the $20,000 (the basis) is taxable now as ordinary phantom income.  

The $180,000 is always LTCG. If the client sells the stock for $230,000, the $30,000 of extra gain is either STCG or LTCG depending on the holding period between distribution and sale.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Nonqualifed Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack: "Nonqualified" is any employer retirement, savings, or deferred compensation plan for employees that does not meet the tax and labor laws' (ERISA) requirements applicable to qualified pension and profit-sharing plans. There are no immediate tax deductions for the employer.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Characteristics of
Nonqualified Plan
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• May discriminate
  • Exempt from most ERISA requirements
  • No employer tax deductions for contributions until employee is taxed
  • Plan earnings taxable to employer
  • Distributions generally taxable at ordinary tax rates

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Rabbi Trust
(Informal Funding)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Assets in rabbi trust available to company's creditors
  • Fear that ownership / management may change before deferred compensation is paid
Key Words -merger, acquisition, or change of ownership

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Incentive Stock Options 
ISOs
Holding Period
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
For long-term gains treatment on the sale of ISO stock:
 
Holding Period:
1 year from exercise dateand2 years from grant before selling ISOs

Violating either rule results in a disqualifying disposition.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Easier to Administer
Retirement Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The following plans are relatively easy to install and maintain.
  • SEP
  • SIMPLE
  • SARSEP (no new plans can be installed)
  • 403(b) - can be subject to ERISA if employer contributes

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Community Property
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Presumes income generated and property acquired by spouses during marriage belongs equally toboth spouses

  • Operates in 9 states and to migrating couples

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Non-community property interest (Separate Property)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Includes: 

  1. Income earned by spousespriorto marriage
  2. Property received as agiftby one spouse
  3. Propertyinheritedby one spouse

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Joint Tenancy With
Right of Survivorship
JTWROS
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Property can be held by spouses, parent and child or children, siblings, and business partners
  • Control, ownership and enjoyment shared equally by all joint tenants
  • Upon death of each tenant, property immediately passes to surviving joint tenants in equal shares
  • Property NOT controlled by terms of the will
  • NOT subject to probate
NOTE:  On exam may be referred to as JT

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Tenancy By the Entirety
TBE
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Ownership can only be held by spouses

  • Transfer of property can only occur with the mutual consent of both parties

  • In most states property is protected from the claims of each spouse's separate creditors, but NOT protected from the claims of both spouse's (joint) creditors

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Tenancy In Common
TIC
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Two or more owners each own an undivided interest in the property

  • Any income is distributed according to each owner's respective share in the property

  • Owners are free to transfer their respective share of the property to other individuals

  • Ownership interest goes through probate upon death

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Life Insurance must be
Added to the Probate Estate
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Life insurance becomes probatable when:
  • Proceeds are paid to the executor of the decedent's estate
  • Decedent owned a policy under which someone else was the insured

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Life Insurance in the Gross Estate
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Decedent held incidents of ownership at death or within 3 years of death 
NOTE:  Naming beneficiary is an incident of ownership but paying premium is NOT

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Assets Subject to Probate
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• "Singly" owned assets
  • Property held by tenancy in common
  • Assets where the beneficiary is the "estate of the insured"
  • Community Property (CP) ½ per spouse
NOTE:  In general property passing by will

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Assets NOT Subject to Probate
(Will Substitutes)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Property conveyed by deeds of title (beneficiary arrangements)
  • Property held by joint tenancy with rights of survivorship (TBE)
  • Revocable living trusts
  • Payable on death accounts (PODs)
  • Transfer on death accounts (TODs)
  • Totten trust

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Revocable Trusts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If a revocable trust is funded (either before incompetency or by the attorney-in-fact), the grantor can also write provisions that specify management by the trustee in the event of the grantor's incompetency.
  • Two advantages:
    • trustee's authority to act in managing assets may be recognized, and
    • can be enforced while a durable power of attorney may not be.
  • Revocable trust continues after death while a durable power becomes invalid at death.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Assets Included in Gross Estate
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Singly owned assets - included in probate estate
  • Tenancy in common - included in probate estate
  • Beneficiary is the estate - included in probate estate
  • Community property - included in probate estate
  • JTWROS/Entirety
  • Life Insurance
  • General Powers
  • 3-year gross-up on gift taxes paid (but NOT GST taxes paid)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Deductions from 
Adjusted Gross Estate
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Martial Deduction:
An "unlimited" amount of property passing to the surviving spouse can pass estate-tax free if these requirements are met:

  • Property must be included in the decedent's gross estate.

  • Property must actually pass to the surviving spouse.

Chartiable Deduction:
Outright transfers to qualified charities are 100% deductible for both estate and gift tax purposes.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Marital Deduction
Requirements and Transfers
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Spousal Qualifying Requirements
  • Property included in the decedent's gross estate
  • Property actually passes to the surviving spouse
  • Interest passing to spouse that is not a terminal interest
  • Receiving spouse must be a U.S. citizen
Qualifying Transfers
  • Property transfers outright
  • Property passes to marital trust, estate trust, or QTIP

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Inter-vivosGifting
(Lifetime Gifting)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Transfer of property is made while the transferor is alive.
     
  • For gift purposes, a gift can be broadly defined to include a sale, exchange, or other transfer of property from one person (donor) to another (donee) without adequate and full consideration in money or money's worth.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Appropriate Gift Property
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Type of propertyDonee
Highly appreciated property
Charity or a donee in a lower tax bracket
NOTE: May want to keep this property until death to get a step-up in basis
Property likely to appreciate
Good to gift to remove future value from donor's estate
Income-producing property
Good to gift only if donee is in a lower tax bracket

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Valuation of a Gift
CardContent.FlashCardBack: The value of a gift for gift tax purposes is its fair market value (FMV) at the date of gift.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Basis of a Gift
(Loss Property)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Basis for "loss" property gifts:
  • If FMV on the date of gift is greater than the donor's adjusted basis, use the donor's adjusted basis
  • If the FMV of the gift is less than the donor's adjusted basis, use the chart below

Client's substituted basis$1,200,000                 Gain
between $1.2M and $660,000no gain or loss

FMV date of gift

_____________________
$660,000                    Loss

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Gifts Reported on the
Federal Estate Tax Form (706)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Generally gifts given are simply "adjusted taxable gifts" to the extent such gifts exceed the annual exclusion.
  • Adjusted taxable gifts are added to the taxable estate.
  • Gift taxes paid (or payable) are generally allowed as a credit against the tentative tax.
  • Gift taxes paid on any gifts within three years of death are added to the gross estate.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Gift Tax Filing Requirements
(Form 709)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
In general a gift tax return (Form 709) must be filed by any individual donor who, in any calendar year, gives the following:
  • more than $10K indexed $15K -2018 to any non-spouse donee,
  • a gift of a future interest in any amount, or
  • a gift for which spouses want to elect gift splitting.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Gift Splitting
(by spouses to others)
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Splitting treats a gift of the property owned by one spouse as if it were made one-half by each spouse.   To make the split gift election, the consent of the non-donor spouse is required, and two gift tax returns (one by each spouse) must be filed by spouses if, after the split the values exceed the annual exclusion. Only the donor spouse needs to file a gift tax return if the split brings the gift below the annual exclusion.  However, there is a place on the donor spouse's tax return for the non-donor to sign, affirming his/her consent to the election.  The spouse signs the consent.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Deductible Gifts
(not taxable gifts)
also called exempt gifts or
qualified transfer
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Gifts to a spouse, provided they are not a terminal interest
  • Gifts to qualified charities
  • Qualified payments in any amount madedirectlyto an educational institution for tuition
  • Qualified payments in any amount madedirectlyto a medical care provider on behalf of any individual
  • Gifts to political parties

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Present Interest Gifts
vs.
Future Interest Gifts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Present interest gifts generally quality for the annual gift tax exclusion
  • Coverdell ESAs
  • UGMA
  • UTMA
  • 2503(c) trust
  • Section 529 college savings plan

Outright gifts of cash and/or property:
Gift to a 2503(b) trust is a gift of afutureinterest. Future interest gifts do not quality for the annual gift tax exclusion, and the client must use his/her $11,180,000 exemption.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Characteristics of UGMA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Must be funded with cash-type assets (i.e., EEs, securities, mutual funds)
  • Normally distributed at age 18
  • Can be included in the custodian's estate

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Characteristics of UTMA
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Can be funded with any type of asset including real estate

  • Normally distributed at age 21

  • Can be included in custodian's estate

  • Can be established by will

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Section 2503(b) Trusts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Can be used for minors*
  • Provides a minor with stream of income
  • Can be disadvantage due to kiddie tax
  • Two parts:  Income interest and remainder or reversion interest
  • Tax law considers income to be a gift of present interest and the remainder interest (corpus) to be a gift of a future interest with only income needing to be distributed 
*2503(b) trusts are more typically used for adult children to avoid kiddie tax problems.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Section 2503(c) Trust
(Minor's Trust)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Enables a grantor to make a gift to a minor in trust and still obtain the annual gift tax exclusion
  • Gift will not be considered a gift of a future interest if these conditions are met
  • Trust assets must be available to beneficiary no later than age 21

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Section 529
College Savings Plans
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Donor can contribute maximum $75K in a year per beneficiary ($150K married) with no gift tax
  • Donor can take the $15K exclusion for the next five years
    • If death occurs before the end of that period, the portion of the gift that would have been allocated in ensuing years would be included in the estate
  • Donor retains control of the qualified state tuition plan account and has option of taking the money back at any time
  • May now use up to the $10K per year to pay for K-12 tuition

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Crummey Trust
Provisions
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Operates in irrevocable trust with demand rights
     
  • Demand right given to a minor through his/her guardian
     
  • Beneficiary has temporary right to demand a withdrawal from the trust that is thelesserof the amount of the annual gift exclusion or the value of the gift transferred
  • Creates present interest gift and this qualifies for annual gift tax exclusion

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Incapacity
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Definition:  The lack of physical or intellectual power or of legal qualifications; the quality or state of being incapable.
 
Incapacitated individuals are not valid contract parties

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Powers of Attorney
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Traditional, non-durable power of attorney -Power ceases when the principal is no longer legally competent

Durable power of attorney- Authority of agent continues when principal becomes incompetent

Springing  durable power of attorney- Main strength is the agent has no authority over the principal's assetsuntilincompetency

NOTE: All powers of attorney expire on death

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Attorney-in-fact
Tax-Related Powers
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
An attorney in fact (agent) holds the power to the following:
  • Make gifts to the spouse and to children, grandchildren, etc.
  • Make disclaimers
  • Make living trusts to benefit principal, spouse, and heirs
  • Complete transfers to a living trust, if the principal becomes incompetent
  • Join the competent spouse in signing income and gift tax returns
  • Exercise special powers of appointment

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Living Wills
(Advance Medical Directives)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Directs the client's physician to discontinue life-sustaining procedures if the client is in a terminal condition or permanently unconscious.  

A final expression of the client's right to refuse medical treatment.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Elements of a Trust
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• In order for a trust to exist, there must beproperty(also known as principal, or corpus).
  • There must be agrantor. This is any person who transfers property to and dictates the term of a trust.
  • There must be a trustee,who receiveslegal titleto the property placed in the trust, and who generally manages and distributes income according to the terms of a formal written agreement (trust instrument).
  • There must be abeneficiary,who hasequitable titleto the property.
  • The grantor and trustee must be legally competent.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Simple vs. Complex Trusts
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Simple trusts [2503(b), Martial, QTIP] are considered merely a "conduit" for forwarding income to the beneficiaries (pass-through)
  • Complex trusts [2503(c)], are separate tax entities and taxed as such if it meets the following two requirements:
    • It is irrevocable and the grantor has not retained any control
    • Income is or may be accumulated

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Revocable Living Trusts 
Inter vivos
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Popular alternative to probate for many
    estate planning clients
  • Most grantors name themselves as trustee.
  • At trustor's death, the revocable trust becomes irrevocable and either terminates with the corpus distributed to the remainderman or continues until a later date.
  • Usually has no gift tax consequence during the grantor's lifetime
  • Undergrantortrustrules, all income earned by a revocable trust is taxable to grantor.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Irrevocable Trusts
CardContent.FlashCardBack: The grantor completely gives up all rights in the property transferred to the trust. Then, the grantor holds no rights to revoke, terminate, or modify the trust in any material way. It becomes a nongrantor trust. Mainly used to either minimize or pay estate taxes.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Inter-vivosTrusts
Advantages and Disadvantages
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Advantages
  • Organization of property during lifetime
  • Potentially lower cost than probate
  • Alternative to guardianship or conservatorship
  • Greater privacy
  • Speed of disposal of property
  • Avoidance of probate
Disadvantages
  • Legal fees to prepare
  • Funding burden
  • Longer creditor period

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Testamentary Trust
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Trust created by a will

  • Designates a person to serve as trustee, names the beneficiaries of the trust, and includes directions on how assets are to be administered. 

  • Does not automatically take effect upon the death of a decedent; it can become effectiveonlyif the will creating the trust is admitted to probate.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Nonmarital "B" Trust
(Family, Bypass, Credit Shelter, Unified Credit Shelter)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Property transferred to the trust at time of decedent's death
  • Uses estate tax exemption rather than the marital deduction
  • Can be structured to provide a stream of income to surviving spouse or other individuals
  • Decedent has postmortem control

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
QTIP "C" Trust
(Current Income Trust)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Must elect marital deduction
  • Provides surviving spouse with income for life, but decedent has postmortem control of trust property
  • Mainly used for second marriages
  • Key words for QTIP - LAME
    Lifetime income for the spouse
    Annual payments to spouse
    Mandatory payments to spouse
    Exclusively for spouse
NOTE:  If LAME is not part of the question/answer then the trust is not a QTIP.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
General Power of Appointment
vs.
Special Power of Appointment
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
General:  subject to estate tax and gift tax implications
 
Special:  not subject to gift tax or estate tax implications

CardContent.FlashCardFront: "5 or 5" Power
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
The five or five power is a common clause included in many trusts allowing the beneficiary to withdraw the greater of $5,000 or 5% of the trust's assets each year.  

If the beneficiary's power to withdraw the trust's assets is limited to $5,000 or 5%, then only that amount should be included in the beneficiary's estate for estate tax purposes. 
 
If the beneficiary can withdraw more than $5,000 or 5% of the trust's assets, the beneficiary could be deemed to have a general power over the trust and some or all of the trust's assets could be included in the beneficiary's estate.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Transfer to a Non-Citizen Spouse
Qualified Domestic Trust
(QDT/QDOT)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• No unlimited estate tax marital deduction for non-citizen spouse
  • The exemption amount is available unless the spouse is a non-resident alien.
  • Jointly held property between spouses is not considered one-half owned
  • Limited gift between spouses of only 100K (indexed) per year
  • Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT) re-establishes martial deduction for certain transfers to a non-citizen spouse.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Charitable Remainder Annuity Trust CRAT
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• No additions
  • Payments fixed (lifetime or term certain) - minimum 5%
  • Payable to any charity
  • 10% ending value to charity or deduction lost

Disadvantage
  • Subject to inflation exposure

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Charitable Remainder Unit Trust
CRUT
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Additions allowed
  • Payments variable (assets revalued annually) - minimum 5%
  • Can be lifetime or term certain like a CRAT
  • Payable to any charity
  • 10% ending value
Advantage
  • Potential inflation protection

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Charitable Lead Trusts
CLAT / CLUT
Death Only 
(0%)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• If trust is established at death, there is no income tax deduction
  • After a term, principal distributed to a non-charitable beneficiary

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Comparing
CharitableTransfers
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Income to donor until donor's death:

  • Charitable Remainder Annuity Trust (CRAT) - 5% minimum
  • Charitable Remainder Unitrust (CRUT) - 5% minimum
  • Pooled Income Fund - no 5% required
  • Charitable Gift Annuity - no 5% required

Income to charity:

  • Charitable Lead Trust (CLAT/CLUT) - no 5% required
  • Private Foundation - 5% minimum required - can give money to individuals

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Private Foundations
Advantages / Disadvantages
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Advantages
  • Donor has complete control over amounts and recipients
  • 5% must be distributed annually
  • Can distribute gifts to talented individuals
Disadvantages
  • Exempt from federal income tax, but they are subject to excise taxes.
  • 15% penalty is applied if annual 5% of the average fair market asset values is not distributed.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Intrafamily Transfers
Property owner needs income
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Intra-family transfer techniques where grantor retains income include:

  • Private Annuity
  • Installment Sale
  • Grantor Retained Annuity Trusts (GRAT/GRUT)
  • Self-cancelling installment note (SCIN)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Intrafamily Transfers
Property owner wants to gift assets and/or income to family members
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Partnership / S corporation
  • Family Limited Partnership (FLP)
  • Gift Leaseback
  • Qualified Personal Residence Trust (QPRT)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Family Limited Partnership
FLP
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Requirements
  • General partner may own as little as 1%.
  • Income and tax benefits must be distributed or allocated according to each owner's percentage in the partnership.
  • The general partners may be paid for their personal service to the partnership (retains control).
  • Capital must be a material income-producing factor.  Income cannot come from personal services of the general partner.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Grantor Trust Rules

(Tainted / Defective Trusts)
Income Tax & Estate Exposure
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
An irrevocable trust may be defective / tainted for income tax and estate tax purposes if the grantor retains:
  1. A right to income or the right to use/enjoy trust property (beneficial enjoyment).
  2. A reversionary interest exceeding 5% (retained interest)

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Qualified Personal Residence Trust
QPRT
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Irrevocable trust into which a person (grantor) transfers his/her personal residence, retaining an interest for his/her personal occupancy and use for a period of years, after which the residence passes to the beneficiaries of the trust, either outright or in trust.  

The retained interest lowers "transferred" amount for gift tax purposes.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Payment of the
Generation Skipping Tax
GST
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
1. If the transfer is a direct skip, the transferor pays it.
  2. If the transfer is a taxable termination, the GST tax is paid by the trustee from trust assets.
  3. If the transfer is a taxable distribution, the GST tax is paid by the transferee.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Fiduciaries
CardContent.FlashCardBack: Person or entity that occupies a position of special trust in relation to the other person.  This often involves holding legal title to the property that must be handled for the sole benefit of the beneficial owner.  It may also involve making personal decisions for the person, just as a guardian does.  Beside personal representatives, fiduciaries include executors, trustees, guardians, conservators and agents.

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Postmortem Planning Techniques
for the Business Owner
(Sections 303 and 6166)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Stock Redemption (Section 303)

  1. Business must be incorporated (closely held)
  2. Value of business must exceed 35% of decedent's adjusted gross estate
  3. Redemption cannot exceed the sum of the estate taxes plus administration expenses

Installment payment of estate taxes (Section 6166)

  1. Value of business must exceed 35% of decedent's adjusted gross estate
  2. During the first 4 years (of 14 years) can pay interest only on taxes due
6166 and 303 provides estate liquidity

CardContent.FlashCardFront:
Postmortem Planning Techniques
(Section 2032A)
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
Special Use Valuation (Section 2032A):

  1. 50% of the gross estate must consist of real and personal property used in the business 

  2. 25% of the gross estate consists of real property used in the business

  3. Must be in qualified use  5-out-of-8 year rule before death and 10 years after death
2032A provides estate tax deduction

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Alternate Valuation Date
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
• Using it must cause a reduction in the total value of the gross estate.
  • The amount of federal tax liability must be reduced as a result of filing the election.
  • The AVD must be applied to all properties included in the gross estate.
  • The AVD cannot be used on assets that have a value that decreases with the mere passing of time.
  • May not be longer than 6 months.

CardContent.FlashCardFront: Qualified Disclaimer
CardContent.FlashCardBack:
In order to disclaim property, the following requirements must be met:

  1. Disclaimer must be an irrevocable refusal to accept the interest
  2. Refusal must be in writing
  3. Refusal must be received within nine months
  4. Intended donee cannot have accepted any interest in the benefits
  5. As a result of refusal, the interest will pass, without the disclaiming person's direction, to someone else
